question_details.query: What methods are available to control disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies have identified several methods for controlling disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms. For sea lice control, two studies in Ireland found mixed effects of using cleaner wrasse - corkwing and goldskinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments, while rockcook wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks. Altering lighting intensity was found to reduce lice numbers, with lower intensity artificial light or natural lighting resulting in fewer lice. Fallowing systems showed mixed results, with one study in Scotland recording lower lice numbers but another in Australia finding no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease. For disease prevention and control, vaccinations were found to increase survival rates against various pathogens including Aeromonas salmonicida spp. achromogenes, Yersinia ruckeri, marine flexibacteriosis, bacterial kidney disease, and infectious salmon anaemia in studies from Iceland, Norway, Australia and Canada. Using probiotics and immunostimulants showed benefits including increased survival when salmon were exposed to disease-causing bacteria, with one study finding a 28% reduction in lice infection when fish were fed a diet with 28% plant-based protein, and a further 28% reduction when beta-glucans were added. Freshwater bathing to reduce amoebic gill disease showed mixed results, with one study finding reduced amoebae on gills for up to 10 days, while another found no difference between treated and untreated salmon.
summary_statements: Studies have identified several methods for controlling disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms.
For sea lice control, studies in Ireland found mixed effects of using cleaner wrasse.
Corkwing and goldskinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments for controlling sea lice.
Rockcook wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks.
Altering lighting intensity was found to reduce lice numbers in Atlantic salmon.
Lower intensity artificial light or natural lighting resulted in fewer lice.
Fallowing systems showed mixed results for controlling lice and disease.
A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers in salmon farms that used fallowing systems.
A study in Australia found no difference in salmon mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease when using fallowing systems.
For disease prevention and control, vaccinations were found to increase salmon survival rates against various pathogens.
Vaccinations increased survival rates against pathogens including Aeromonas salmonicida spp.
achromogenes, Yersinia ruckeri, marine flexibacteriosis, bacterial kidney disease, and infectious salmon anaemia.
Using probiotics and immunostimulants showed benefits including increased survival when salmon were exposed to disease-causing bacteria.
One study found a 28% reduction in lice infection when fish were fed a diet with 28% plant-based protein.
A further 28% reduction in lice infection occurred when beta-glucans were added to the salmon's diet.
Freshwater bathing to reduce amoebic gill disease in salmon showed mixed results.
One study found that freshwater bathing reduced amoebae on salmon gills for up to 10 days.
Another study found no difference in amoebic gill disease between salmon that were treated with freshwater baths and untreated salmon.

question_details.query: How do plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal compare in terms of their effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates in Norway?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on multiple studies from Norway, plant-based protein alternatives to fish meal generally result in decreased growth rates in Atlantic salmon. Six studies found reduced growth rates with plant-based diets, while three studies found similar growth rates compared to fish meal controls. Plant-based diets also showed reduced final body weights in four studies, with mixed effects on feeding efficiency - some studies showed lowered efficiency while others showed increased efficiency. Fish meal reduction studies found no significant differences in final weights.

Bacterial protein alternatives showed more favorable results. Two replicated controlled studies in Norway found similar growth rates when bacterial protein replaced up to 25% of fish meal, though 50% replacement resulted in lower growth rates. Another study actually reported higher growth rates with diets containing 18% and 36% bacterial protein compared to fish meal controls, suggesting bacterial protein may be superior to plant-based alternatives in maintaining salmon growth performance.
summary_statements: Based on multiple studies from Norway, plant-based protein alternatives to fish meal generally result in decreased growth rates in Atlantic salmon.
Six studies found reduced growth rates in Atlantic salmon with plant-based diets.
Three studies found similar growth rates in Atlantic salmon with plant-based diets compared to fish meal controls.
Plant-based diets showed reduced final body weights of Atlantic salmon in four studies.
Plant-based diets for Atlantic salmon had mixed effects on feeding efficiency.
Some studies showed that plant-based diets lowered feeding efficiency in Atlantic salmon, while other studies showed increased efficiency.
Studies on the reduction of fish meal in Atlantic salmon diets found no significant differences in final weights.
Bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal showed more favorable results for Atlantic salmon growth.
Two replicated controlled studies in Norway found similar growth rates in Atlantic salmon when bacterial protein replaced up to 25% of fish meal.
Replacing 50% of fish meal with bacterial protein resulted in lower growth rates in Atlantic salmon.
One study reported higher growth rates in Atlantic salmon with diets containing 18% and 36% bacterial protein compared to fish meal controls.
Evidence suggests bacterial protein may be superior to plant-based alternatives in maintaining salmon growth performance.

question_details.query: Which interventions appear most effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from controlled studies, several interventions show effectiveness for increasing survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease. Vaccinations demonstrated higher survival rates across multiple studies, including protection against Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes, Yersinia ruckeri, marine flexibacteriosis, bacterial kidney disease, and infectious salmon anaemia. Breeding for resistance traits showed increased survival in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis. Use of probiotics and immunostimulants increased survival against disease-causing bacteria and reduced lice infection by 28% while also improving gut function. Aerobic training resulted in higher survival rates for salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis, with interval training being more effective than continuous training. Establishing fallowing systems showed mixed results, with reduced lice numbers in one study but no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in another.
summary_statements: Based on evidence from controlled studies, several interventions are effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease.
Vaccinations demonstrated higher survival rates for farmed salmon.
Vaccinations provide protection against Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes.
Vaccinations provide protection against Yersinia ruckeri.
Vaccinations provide protection against marine flexibacteriosis.
Vaccinations provide protection against bacterial kidney disease.
Vaccinations provide protection against infectious salmon anaemia.
Breeding for resistance traits showed increased survival in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis.
The use of probiotics and immunostimulants increased survival of farmed salmon against disease-causing bacteria.
The use of probiotics and immunostimulants reduced lice infection by 28%.
The use of probiotics and immunostimulants improved gut function in farmed salmon.
Aerobic training resulted in higher survival rates for salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis.
Interval aerobic training was more effective than continuous aerobic training for salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis.
Establishing fallowing systems showed mixed results for farmed salmon health.
Fallowing systems reduced lice numbers in farmed salmon.
Fallowing systems showed no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease.

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of using plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated, controlled studies found that digestibility of feed components by salmon was lower when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal, while two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway found similar levels of digestibility across both diet types. Two studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However, morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies.
summary_statements: Six studies in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that the inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon.
Four replicated, controlled studies from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets.
A replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies found that the digestibility of feed components by salmon was lower when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal.
Two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway found similar levels of digestibility between plant-based protein diets and fish meal-based diets.
Two studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by either plant-based or fish meal-based protein diets.
The morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins.
The condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study.
The condition of the salmon was reduced in plant-based protein diets in two other replicated studies.

question_details.query: What are the non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the research evidence, several non-chemical alternatives exist for controlling sea lice on salmon farms. The use of cleaner wrasse as natural control agents shows mixed results - corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were found to be as effective as chemical treatments in one controlled study in Ireland, while rockcook cleaner wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks in another study. Altering lighting conditions is another non-chemical approach, with a replicated, controlled study in Norway showing that lower numbers of lice were found on salmon kept in low intensity artificial light or natural lighting, where higher intensity artificial light led to higher lice numbers.

Fallowing systems represent another alternative, with a study in Scotland recording lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using this approach, though another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease where fallowing had been used. Probiotics and immunostimulants show promise - a replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before bacterial exposure, while a Norwegian study found that feeding salmon a diet with 28% plant-based protein reduced lice infection by 28%, and adding beta-glucans decreased infection levels by a further 28% compared to controls.
summary_statements: Several non-chemical alternatives exist for controlling sea lice on salmon farms.
The use of cleaner wrasse as natural control agents for sea lice shows mixed results.
Corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were found to be as effective as chemical treatments for controlling sea lice in a controlled study.
Rockcook cleaner wrasse were found to be ineffective at preventing sea lice outbreaks in a study.
Altering lighting conditions is a non-chemical approach for controlling sea lice.
Lower numbers of sea lice were found on salmon kept in low intensity artificial light or natural lighting.
Higher intensity artificial light led to higher numbers of sea lice on salmon.
Fallowing systems represent a non-chemical alternative for controlling sea lice.
A study recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system approach.
A study found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease where fallowing had been used.
Probiotics and immunostimulants show promise for controlling sea lice.
A replicated study found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before bacterial exposure.
Feeding salmon a diet with 28% plant-based protein reduced sea lice infection by 28%.
Adding beta-glucans to a salmon's diet decreased sea lice infection levels by a further 28% compared to controls.

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of fallowing salmon farm cages for disease control vary between studies in Scotland and Australia?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies comparing the effectiveness of fallowing salmon farm cages for disease control show contrasting results between Scotland and Australia. In Scotland, a study found that fallowing systems successfully reduced sea lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages (action 1026). However, in Australia, research found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where fallowing systems had been used (action 1026). The evidence suggests that fallowing may be effective for controlling parasites like sea lice in Scottish waters, but shows no beneficial effect against Amoebic Gill Disease in Australian salmon farming operations.
summary_statements: Studies comparing the effectiveness of fallowing salmon farm cages for disease control show contrasting results between Scotland and Australia.
In Scotland, a study found that fallowing systems successfully reduced sea lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages.
In Australia, research found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where fallowing systems had been used.
Evidence suggests that fallowing may be effective for controlling parasites like sea lice in Scottish waters.
Fallowing shows no beneficial effect against Amoebic Gill Disease in Australian salmon farming operations.

question_details.query: How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies show that krill meal and yeast meal produce similar weight gain in Atlantic salmon compared to fishmeal, while animal protein alternatives result in lower weight. Two replicated studies in Norway found similar final weight gain between salmon fed diets containing fish meal only or krill meal substitutes, with feed conversion ratios being similar between fish meal and krill meal diets. One study found that when krill were de-shelled, growth rates were closer to salmon fed fish meal compared to leaving the krill whole. One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon that were fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica compared to a control diet containing fishmeal. However, one controlled, randomized, replicated study from Scotland showed that fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with animal proteins.
summary_statements: Krill meal and yeast meal produce similar weight gain in Atlantic salmon compared to fishmeal.
Animal protein alternatives result in lower weight gain in Atlantic salmon compared to fishmeal.
Salmon fed diets containing only fish meal had similar final weight gain to salmon fed diets with krill meal substitutes.
Feed conversion ratios were similar between fish meal and krill meal diets for salmon.
When krill were de-shelled, salmon growth rates were closer to salmon fed fish meal compared to leaving the krill whole.
No differences in weight were found between Atlantic salmon fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica and those fed a control diet containing fishmeal.
Fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with animal proteins.

question_details.query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway for using alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Norwegian studies on alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets have shown mixed results:

Genetically Modified Alternatives: Three controlled, replicated studies (two randomized) found no difference in growth rate between Atlantic salmon fed GM versus non-GM soybeans. One randomized, replicated, controlled study found no differences in fish histology between GM and non-GM soy diets.

Yeast Protein: One replicated, controlled experiment found no differences in weight between salmon fed diets containing Yarrowia lipolytica yeast compared to fishmeal control diets.

Plant-Based Protein: Multiple studies found that plant-based proteins decreased growth rates and final body weights in some cases, while other studies found similar growth rates compared to fish meal diets. Some studies showed reduced feeding efficiency and digestibility with plant proteins, altered intestinal morphology, but no effects on survival rates or appetite.

Bacterial Protein: Two replicated, controlled studies found similar growth rates when up to 25% fish meal was replaced with bacterial protein, but lower growth rates at 50% replacement. Another study reported higher growth rates with 18% and 36% bacterial protein inclusion.

Vegetable Oil: Three replicated studies (two controlled) found similar growth rates between fish oil and vegetable oil diets, with some studies finding higher growth rates with vegetable oil. Studies showed that fatty acid profiles reflected the oil source, with no effects on broodstock fecundity, egg weights, or fertility rates. Vegetable oil diets resulted in lower dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyl concentrations in salmon flesh.
summary_statements: Norwegian studies on alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets have shown mixed results.
Studies found no difference in growth rate between Atlantic salmon fed genetically modified (GM) soybeans and Atlantic salmon fed non-GM soybeans.
One study found no differences in fish histology between Atlantic salmon on GM soy diets and those on non-GM soy diets.
An experiment found no differences in weight between salmon fed diets containing Yarrowia lipolytica yeast and salmon fed fishmeal control diets.
Some studies found that plant-based proteins decreased growth rates and final body weights in Atlantic salmon.
Other studies found that Atlantic salmon fed plant-based proteins had similar growth rates compared to those fed fish meal diets.
Some studies showed that using plant proteins in salmon diets resulted in reduced feeding efficiency and digestibility.
Some studies showed that plant proteins altered the intestinal morphology of Atlantic salmon.
Some studies showed that plant proteins in salmon diets had no effects on survival rates or appetite.
Studies found similar growth rates in Atlantic salmon when up to 25% of fish meal in their diet was replaced with bacterial protein.
Studies found lower growth rates in Atlantic salmon when 50% of fish meal in their diet was replaced with bacterial protein.
Another study reported higher growth rates in Atlantic salmon with diet inclusions of 18% and 36% bacterial protein.
Some studies found similar growth rates between Atlantic salmon fed fish oil diets and those fed vegetable oil diets.
Some studies found higher growth rates in Atlantic salmon that were fed vegetable oil diets.
Studies showed that the fatty acid profiles in Atlantic salmon reflected the oil source in their diet.
The use of vegetable oil in diets had no effects on broodstock fecundity, egg weights, or fertility rates of Atlantic salmon.
Vegetable oil diets resulted in lower dioxin concentrations in salmon flesh.
Vegetable oil diets resulted in lower polychlorinated biphenyl concentrations in salmon flesh.

question_details.query: What are the effects of altering the physical environment of salmon cages, such as their size or lighting, on salmon health in aquaculture?
How do different non-chemical water-based treatments, such as fallowing and freshwater bathing, compare in their reported effectiveness for specific diseases in salmon?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Freshwater bathing for amoebic gill disease shows mixed effectiveness in studies. Two studies in Australia found that while one study showed a reduction in numbers of amoebae on salmon gills persisting for up to 10 days after bathing, one replicated controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in the gills of treated and untreated salmon. For fallowing systems, the effectiveness varies by disease type. A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system. However, an Australian study found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used. An additional benefit was noted where a trial in Tasmania found sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles.
summary_statements: Freshwater bathing for amoebic gill disease shows mixed effectiveness.
A reduction in the numbers of amoebae on salmon gills can persist for up to 10 days after freshwater bathing.
Similar levels of amoebae have been found in the gills of salmon treated with freshwater bathing and in the gills of untreated salmon.
The effectiveness of fallowing systems varies by disease type.
Lower lice numbers were recorded on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system.
No difference was found in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used.
Sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles.

question_details.query: Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence, several dietary alternatives and supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight. Taurine supplementation showed no difference in weight gain compared to diets without taurine (Action ID: 930). Similarly, phytase and phosphate supplementation showed no difference in weight gain in one Australian study, while another Australian study actually found greater final weights in salmon fed diets supplemented with phytase (Action ID: 930). Genetically modified soybeans used as an alternative to fish meal resulted in no difference in growth rate compared to non-GM soybeans (Action ID: 928). Krill meal as a substitute for fish meal resulted in similar final weight gain and feed conversion ratios compared to fish meal diets (Action ID: 916). Yeast protein from Yarrowia lipolytica showed no differences in weight compared to control fishmeal diets (Action ID: 920). Additionally, diets with low, medium, or high levels of fish meal resulted in similar final weights (Action ID: 915). Plant-based oil sources as alternatives to fish oil showed similar or even higher growth rates in salmon (Action ID: 926).
summary_statements: Several dietary alternatives and supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight.
Taurine supplementation showed no difference in weight gain compared to diets without taurine.
In one Australian study, phytase and phosphate supplementation showed no difference in weight gain.
Another Australian study found greater final weights in salmon fed diets supplemented with phytase.
Genetically modified soybeans used as an alternative to fish meal resulted in no difference in growth rate compared to non-genetically modified soybeans.
Krill meal as a substitute for fish meal resulted in similar final weight gain and feed conversion ratios compared to fish meal diets.
Yeast protein from Yarrowia lipolytica showed no differences in weight compared to control fishmeal diets.
Diets with low, medium, or high levels of fish meal resulted in similar final weights.
Plant-based oil sources as alternatives to fish oil showed similar or even higher growth rates in salmon.

question_details.query: What is the evidence that integrated aquaculture systems or constructing artificial reefs can mitigate the environmental impacts of salmon farms?

summary_details.relevant_summary: There is limited but promising evidence for integrated aquaculture systems mitigating salmon farm impacts, with one Canadian study demonstrating that blue mussels absorbed waste from salmon farms. Additional evidence shows enhanced growth of scallops and algae when placed adjacent to fish farms. However, results are mixed, with some studies finding no evidence of shellfish consuming fish farm waste. For artificial reefs, the evidence is very limited - while two controlled studies examined artificial reefs placed near aquaculture operations to benefit from nutrient run-offs, neither showed significant differences in invertebrate communities compared to control sites. No studies were found evaluating artificial reefs designed specifically as biofilters for salmon farms.
summary_statements: There is limited but promising evidence for integrated aquaculture systems mitigating salmon farm impacts.
One Canadian study demonstrated that blue mussels absorbed waste from salmon farms.
Additional evidence shows enhanced growth of scallops and algae when placed adjacent to fish farms.
The results for using integrated aquaculture systems to mitigate salmon farm impacts are mixed.
Some studies found no evidence of shellfish consuming fish farm waste.
The evidence for using artificial reefs to mitigate the environmental impacts of salmon farms is very limited.
Two controlled studies examined artificial reefs placed near aquaculture operations to benefit from nutrient run-offs.
The two controlled studies showed no significant differences in invertebrate communities on the artificial reefs compared to control sites.
No studies were found evaluating artificial reefs designed specifically as biofilters for salmon farms.

question_details.query: How do physical interventions like aerobic training and altering cage size affect the health and survival of farmed Atlantic salmon?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Aerobic training has been shown to significantly improve survival rates in Atlantic salmon. A randomised, replicated, controlled study in Norway found higher survival rates in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis if they had undergone aerobic training, with interval training being more effective than continuous training.

Cage size also affects Atlantic salmon health outcomes. A replicated study in Australia recorded lower levels of amoebic gill disease in salmon kept within larger compared to smaller cages.
summary_statements: Aerobic training has been shown to significantly improve survival rates in Atlantic salmon.
Atlantic salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis had higher survival rates if the salmon had undergone aerobic training.
Interval training was more effective than continuous training for improving the survival of aerobically trained Atlantic salmon.
Cage size affects Atlantic salmon health outcomes.
Atlantic salmon kept within larger cages had lower levels of amoebic gill disease compared to salmon kept in smaller cages.

question_details.query: What are the observed effects on salmon growth and flesh quality when replacing fish oil with plant-based or other animal-based oils in their diet?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Studies have found mixed effects on salmon growth when replacing fish oil with plant-based oils. Three replicated studies (two controlled) in Norway found similar growth rates in salmon fed diets containing fish oil versus vegetable oil, while one study found higher growth rates in fish fed vegetable oil diets. One replicated, controlled study found salmon growth rates were both lower and higher in vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets, depending on family genetics.

Regarding flesh quality, three replicated studies (two controlled) in Norway and Scotland found that the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected the oil source within diets. A replicated, controlled study found that salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls within flesh compared to diets containing fish oil.

One study in Norway found no differences in salmon flesh quality (gaping, texture, and liquid holding capacity) between fish fed vegetable oil- and fish oil-based diets, though pigment concentration was lower in vegetable oil diets. Studies also noted some physiological differences, with one replicate Norwegian study finding that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to fish oil diets.

One controlled Canadian study on alternative animal-based lipid sources found no difference in oxygen consumption or swimming speed of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing anchovy oil or alternative lipid sources.
summary_statements: Studies have found mixed effects on salmon growth when replacing fish oil with plant-based oils.
Three replicated studies in Norway found similar growth rates in salmon fed diets containing fish oil versus vegetable oil.
One study found higher growth rates in salmon fed vegetable oil diets.
One replicated, controlled study found salmon growth rates were both lower and higher in vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets, depending on family genetics.
Three replicated studies in Norway and Scotland found that the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected the oil source within the salmon's diets.
A replicated, controlled study found that salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls within flesh compared to diets containing fish oil.
One study in Norway found no differences in salmon flesh quality, such as gaping, texture, and liquid holding capacity, between salmon fed vegetable oil- and fish oil-based diets.
A study in Norway found that pigment concentration was lower in salmon fed vegetable oil diets.
One replicate Norwegian study found that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid compared to salmon fed fish oil diets.
One replicate Norwegian study found that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had low plasma lipoprotein compared to salmon fed fish oil diets.
One controlled Canadian study on alternative animal-based lipid sources found no difference in oxygen consumption of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing anchovy oil or alternative lipid sources.
One controlled Canadian study on alternative animal-based lipid sources found no difference in the swimming speed of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing anchovy oil or alternative lipid sources.

question_details.query: What is the evidence regarding the effect of using genetically modified ingredients or dietary supplements on the growth of Atlantic salmon?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three controlled, replicated studies in Norway found no difference in growth rate of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing either GM or non-GM soybeans (Action ID 928). One randomized, replicated, controlled study found no differences in histology of fish fed GM or non-GM soybeans (Action ID 928). Regarding dietary supplements, studies showed mixed results: a controlled, replicated study in Australia found no difference in weight gain with phytase and phosphate supplementation, while another found greater final weights with phytase supplementation (Action ID 930). A controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain with taurine supplementation (Action ID 930). Plant-based protein sources generally led to decreased growth rates compared to fish meal diets, with six studies showing decreased growth and three showing similar growth rates (Action ID 924).
summary_statements: Three controlled, replicated studies in Norway found no difference in the growth rate of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing either genetically modified or non-genetically modified soybeans.
One randomized, replicated, controlled study found no differences in the histology of fish fed genetically modified or non-genetically modified soybeans.
Studies on dietary supplements for Atlantic salmon showed mixed results.
A controlled, replicated study in Australia found no difference in weight gain for Atlantic salmon with phytase and phosphate supplementation.
Another study found that phytase supplementation resulted in greater final weights for Atlantic salmon.
A controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain for Atlantic salmon with taurine supplementation.
Plant-based protein sources generally led to decreased growth rates in Atlantic salmon compared to fish meal diets.
Six studies showed decreased growth in Atlantic salmon fed plant-based protein sources compared to fish meal diets.
Three studies showed similar growth rates in Atlantic salmon fed plant-based protein sources compared to fish meal diets.

question_details.query: What is the evidence from European studies for using vaccinations or probiotics to improve the survival rates of farmed Atlantic salmon?

summary_details.relevant_summary: European studies provide evidence for both vaccinations and probiotics improving survival rates in farmed Atlantic salmon. Two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon post exposure to Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri bacteria. Additional controlled studies in Norway reported similar survival benefits for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia. Regarding probiotics, one replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed probiotics before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28-day period compared to controls. The same Scottish study also demonstrated that probiotic supplementation with mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing soybean-induced enteritis.
summary_statements: European studies provide evidence for both vaccinations and probiotics improving survival rates in farmed Atlantic salmon.
Two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon post exposure to Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri bacteria.
Additional controlled studies in Norway reported similar survival benefits for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia.
One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed probiotics before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28-day period compared to controls.
A replicated study in Scotland demonstrated that probiotic supplementation with mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing soybean-induced enteritis.

question_details.query: What are the documented outcomes of using genetic selection or manipulation, such as breeding for disease resistance or inducing triploidy, in salmon aquaculture?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Documented outcomes from genetic selection and manipulation in salmon aquaculture include: Breeding for disease resistance showed increased survival levels in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis when families were bred for high resistance compared to those bred for low resistance (Action ID: 735). Triploid salmon demonstrated reduced return of stock but maintained similar weight, length and condition compared with diploid salmon (Action ID: 939). Genetically modified soybeans used in salmon feed showed no difference in growth rate between Atlantic salmon fed diets containing GM versus non-GM soybeans, according to three controlled, replicated studies (Action ID: 928). Additionally, one randomised, replicated, controlled study found no differences in histology of fish fed diets containing GM versus non-GM soybeans (Action ID: 928).
summary_statements: Breeding for disease resistance showed increased survival levels in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis.
Salmon families bred for high resistance to infectious pancreatic necrosis had increased survival compared to those bred for low resistance.
Triploid salmon demonstrated a reduced return of stock compared with diploid salmon.
Triploid salmon maintained similar weight, length and condition compared with diploid salmon.
Three controlled, replicated studies showed no difference in growth rate between Atlantic salmon fed diets containing genetically modified versus non-genetically modified soybeans.
One randomised, replicated, controlled study found no differences in the histology of fish fed diets containing genetically modified versus non-genetically modified soybeans.

question_details.query: What are the comparative effects on Atlantic salmon weight when substituting fishmeal with krill, yeast, or other animal-based proteins?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available research evidence, krill meal appears to maintain similar weight gain in Atlantic salmon compared to fishmeal diets. Two studies in Norway found similar final weight gain between salmon fed fish meal only diets versus krill meal substitutes, with better growth rates achieved when krill were de-shelled rather than left whole. Yeast protein (specifically Yarrowia lipolytica) showed no difference in weight compared to control fishmeal diets according to one replicated, controlled experiment in Norway. Animal-based proteins showed mixed results, with one controlled, randomised, replicated study from Scotland demonstrating that salmon fed fishmeal diets weighed more than those fed diets with alternative animal proteins. Bacterial protein demonstrated mixed effects on growth, with studies showing similar growth rates at up to 25% replacement of fishmeal, but reduced growth at 50% replacement. However, some studies reported higher growth rates at 18% and 36% bacterial protein inclusion compared to control.
summary_statements: Krill meal appears to maintain similar weight gain in Atlantic salmon compared to fishmeal diets.
Studies in Norway found similar final weight gain between salmon fed fish meal only diets versus krill meal substitutes.
Better growth rates in Atlantic salmon were achieved when krill were de-shelled rather than left whole.
Yeast protein (specifically Yarrowia lipolytica) showed no difference in Atlantic salmon weight compared to control fishmeal diets.
Animal-based proteins showed mixed results on Atlantic salmon weight.
One study demonstrated that salmon fed fishmeal diets weighed more than salmon fed diets with alternative animal proteins.
Bacterial protein demonstrated mixed effects on the growth of Atlantic salmon.
Studies showed similar growth rates for Atlantic salmon at up to 25% replacement of fishmeal with bacterial protein.
Reduced growth in Atlantic salmon was observed at 50% replacement of fishmeal with bacterial protein.
Some studies reported higher growth rates in Atlantic salmon at 18% and 36% bacterial protein inclusion compared to a control diet.

question_details.query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway regarding the effectiveness of non-dietary interventions for improving farmed Atlantic salmon health and survival?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies from Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated salmon when exposed to disease-causing bacteria (Aeromonas salmonicida spp. achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri) and infectious salmon anaemia. A controlled study in Norway found that aerobic training (particularly interval training) improved salmon survival when exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis. Additionally, a Norwegian study demonstrated that selective breeding for disease resistance traits significantly improved survival rates in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis compared to families bred for low resistance.
summary_statements: Studies from Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated salmon when exposed to the disease-causing bacteria Aeromonas salmonicida spp.
achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri.
Studies from Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated salmon when exposed to infectious salmon anaemia.
A controlled study in Norway found that aerobic training, particularly interval training, improved salmon survival when exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis.
A Norwegian study demonstrated that selective breeding for disease resistance traits significantly improved survival rates in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis.
Salmon selectively bred for disease resistance had improved survival rates compared to families bred for low resistance when exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis.

question_details.query: What actions are available to manage the waste products, such as excess nutrients and sludge, from salmon aquaculture operations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, several actions can be used to manage waste products from salmon aquaculture operations. Integrated aquaculture systems (Action 932) have shown effectiveness where blue mussels can absorb waste from salmon farms, and scallops and algae placed adjacent to fish farms demonstrate enhanced growth. For sludge management specifically, drying sludge in beds (Action 943) has been shown in replicated trials in Canada to effectively remove phosphorus from freshwater fish farm sludge. Other potential approaches include establishing aquaculture facilities specifically to extract nutrients from run-offs (Action 2883), switching to land-based aquaculture systems (Action 3583) which may provide better waste containment, and cleaning wastewater before environmental release (Action 3142). Additional management strategies include minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems (Action 2744), modifying aquaculture practices to reduce pollution (Action 3172), and introducing water quality regulations for aquaculture systems (Action 2876). Using species from multiple trophic levels in aquaculture systems (Action 2195) can also potentially help manage waste through natural biological processes.
summary_statements: Several actions can be used to manage waste products from salmon aquaculture operations.
In integrated aquaculture systems, blue mussels can absorb waste from salmon farms.
Scallops and algae placed adjacent to fish farms demonstrate enhanced growth.
Drying sludge in beds has been shown in replicated trials in Canada to effectively remove phosphorus from freshwater fish farm sludge.
Establishing aquaculture facilities specifically to extract nutrients from run-offs is a potential approach for waste management.
Switching to land-based aquaculture systems may provide better waste containment.
Cleaning wastewater before environmental release is a potential approach for waste management.
Minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems is an additional management strategy.
Modifying aquaculture practices can reduce pollution.
Introducing water quality regulations for aquaculture systems is an additional management strategy.
Using species from multiple trophic levels in aquaculture systems can potentially help manage waste through natural biological processes.

question_details.query: What is the evidence from Australian studies on the effectiveness of different husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Australian studies on husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon show mixed results. Freshwater bathing had mixed effectiveness, with one study finding a reduction in amoebae numbers on salmon gills lasting up to 10 days, while another replicated, controlled study found similar amoebae levels in treated and untreated salmon. Cage size was found to be significant, with a replicated Australian study recording lower levels of Amoebic Gill Disease in salmon kept in larger compared to smaller cages. Fallowing systems showed no evidence of effectiveness, with an Australian study finding no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where fallowing had been used compared to those without fallowing.
summary_statements: Australian studies on husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon show mixed results.
Freshwater bathing had mixed effectiveness for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon.
One study found that freshwater bathing caused a reduction in amoebae numbers on salmon gills that lasted for up to 10 days.
A replicated, controlled study found similar amoebae levels in salmon treated with freshwater bathing and in untreated salmon.
Cage size was found to be a significant factor in managing Amoebic Gill Disease.
A replicated Australian study recorded lower levels of Amoebic Gill Disease in salmon kept in larger cages compared to smaller cages.
Fallowing systems showed no evidence of effectiveness for managing Amoebic Gill Disease.
An Australian study found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where fallowing had been used compared to those without fallowing.

question_details.query: Beyond growth rates, what other biological effects have been observed in salmon fed diets with krill or plant-based proteins instead of fish meal?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Beyond growth rates, several biological effects have been observed in salmon fed diets with alternative protein sources. For plant-based proteins, studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected, but morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomized, replicated, controlled studies (Action ID 924). Digestibility of feed components was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal (Action ID 924). The condition of salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one study but reduced in two other studies (Action ID 924). Two replicated studies found lowered levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets (Action ID 924). For krill meal diets, the number of aerobic bacteria in the hindgut of salmon was higher and the composition of bacterial flora was different compared to fish meal diets (Action ID 916). Additionally, when salmon were fed diets containing 28% plant-based protein combined with beta-glucans, lice infection levels decreased by 28% compared to controls (Action ID 732).
summary_statements: Several biological effects have been observed in salmon fed diets with alternative protein sources.
Survival rates and appetite of salmon were not affected by plant-based protein diets.
The morphology of the distal intestine in salmon was altered by plant-based protein diets.
The digestibility of feed components was lower when diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal.
The condition of salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one study.
The condition of salmon was reduced in plant-based protein diets in two other studies.
Feeding efficiency was lower in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets.
In krill meal diets, the number of aerobic bacteria in the hindgut of salmon was higher compared to fish meal diets.
In krill meal diets, the composition of bacterial flora in the hindgut of salmon was different compared to fish meal diets.
When salmon were fed diets containing 28% plant-based protein combined with beta-glucans, lice infection levels decreased by 28% compared to controls.

question_details.query: What non-chemical methods can be used to manage pests and biofouling on salmon farms?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Non-chemical pest management methods for salmon farms include using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents, with studies showing mixed effectiveness for sea lice control (Action ID: 738). Fallowing systems can reduce parasites and disease, with one Scottish study recording lower lice numbers on salmon in cages using fallowing (Action ID: 1026). Bird pest management employs acoustic deterrents like distress calls, visual deterrents such as scarecrows, and trained raptors, though birds often become habituated to these methods (Action ID: 244). Specific biofouling management actions include preventing biofouling organism attachment and removing biofouling organisms, though no studies have evaluated their effectiveness yet (Action IDs: 2162, 2163). Additional preventive measures involve sourcing disease-free juveniles and implementing regular inspections to avoid introducing problematic species (Action IDs: 2159, 2157).
summary_statements: Non-chemical pest management methods for salmon farms include using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents.
Studies show mixed effectiveness for using cleaner wrasse for sea lice control.
Fallowing systems can reduce parasites and disease on salmon farms.
One Scottish study recorded lower lice numbers on salmon in cages that used fallowing.
Bird pest management employs acoustic deterrents like distress calls and visual deterrents such as scarecrows.
Bird pest management on salmon farms can employ trained raptors.
Birds often become habituated to deterrent methods used for pest management.
Specific biofouling management actions include preventing the attachment of biofouling organisms.
Specific biofouling management actions include removing existing biofouling organisms.
No studies have yet evaluated the effectiveness of preventing or removing biofouling organisms.
Sourcing disease-free juveniles is an additional preventive measure for salmon farms.
Implementing regular inspections can help avoid introducing problematic species to salmon farms.

question_details.query: What factors influence the success of non-pesticide methods for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies show mixed effectiveness of non-pesticide sea lice control methods. Cleaner wrasse effectiveness varies by species - corkwing and goldskinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments, while rockcook wrasse were ineffective (Action ID: 738). Lighting intensity affects lice numbers, with lower intensity artificial light or natural lighting resulting in fewer lice compared to high intensity artificial light (Action ID: 741). Dietary modifications can reduce lice infection - feeding salmon a diet with 28% plant-based protein reduced lice by 28%, and adding beta-glucans decreased infection by a further 28% (Action ID: 732). Fallowing systems showed mixed results, with one study recording lower lice numbers in Scotland but another finding no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in Australia (Action ID: 1026). Vaccinations and breeding for disease resistance improved survival against various pathogens but specific effects on sea lice control were not documented (Action IDs: 733, 735).
summary_statements: Studies show non-pesticide sea lice control methods have mixed effectiveness.
The effectiveness of cleaner wrasse for sea lice control varies by species.
Corkwing and goldskinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments for sea lice control.
Rockcook wrasse were ineffective for sea lice control.
Lighting intensity affects the number of sea lice on salmon.
Lower intensity artificial light or natural lighting resulted in fewer sea lice compared to high intensity artificial light.
Dietary modifications for salmon can reduce sea lice infection.
Feeding salmon a diet with 28% plant-based protein reduced sea lice by 28%.
Adding beta-glucans to a salmon's diet decreased sea lice infection by a further 28%.
Fallowing systems for controlling sea lice showed mixed results.
One study in Scotland recorded lower sea lice numbers when using fallowing systems.
Another study found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in Australia when using fallowing systems.
Vaccinations and breeding for disease resistance improved salmon survival against various pathogens.
The specific effects of vaccinations and breeding for disease resistance on sea lice control were not documented.

question_details.query: In Norway, how do different plant-based feed alternatives, such as vegetable oils versus plant proteins, affect salmon growth and body composition?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Studies in Norway comparing plant-based feed alternatives for salmon show distinct effects between vegetable oils and plant proteins. For vegetable oil alternatives, three replicated studies found similar or higher growth rates in salmon fed vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets. However, the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected the oil source, with vegetable oil diets resulting in high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein levels and lower concentrations of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to fish oil diets. Salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets also had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls in their flesh.

For plant protein alternatives, six studies found that inclusion of plant-based proteins led to decreased growth rates in salmon, with four studies showing reduced final body weights compared to fish meal-based diets. Digestibility of feed components was lower with plant proteins, and morphology of the distal intestine was altered in salmon fed plant-based protein diets. However, survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant-based protein diets.

Both alternatives maintained similar feeding efficiency levels in most studies, though some studies showed either lowered or increased feeding efficiency with plant proteins depending on the specific study conditions.
summary_statements: Studies in Norway comparing plant-based feed alternatives for salmon show distinct effects between vegetable oils and plant proteins.
Salmon fed vegetable oil diets showed similar or higher growth rates compared to salmon fed fish oil diets.
The fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected the oil source used in the diet.
Vegetable oil diets resulted in high liver lipid levels in salmon.
Vegetable oil diets resulted in low plasma lipoprotein levels in salmon.
Vegetable oil diets resulted in lower concentrations of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to fish oil diets.
Salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls in their flesh.
The inclusion of plant-based proteins in feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon.
Four studies showed salmon fed diets with plant proteins had reduced final body weights compared to salmon fed fish meal-based diets.
The digestibility of feed components was lower with plant proteins.
The morphology of the distal intestine was altered in salmon fed plant-based protein diets.
Survival rates of salmon were not affected by plant-based protein diets.
The appetite of salmon was not affected by plant-based protein diets.
Vegetable oil and plant protein feed alternatives generally maintained similar feeding efficiency levels in salmon.
Plant protein diets sometimes resulted in lowered feeding efficiency depending on specific study conditions.
Plant protein diets sometimes resulted in increased feeding efficiency depending on specific study conditions.

question_details.query: What are the documented effects, both positive and negative, of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on evidence from action documents, replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets has shown mixed effects. Negative effects include: decreased growth rates (6 studies from Norway, Scotland, USA), reduced final body weights (4 studies from Norway, Scotland), lowered feeding efficiency (2 studies from Norway), reduced digestibility of feed components (2 studies), altered intestinal morphology (2 studies), and reduced condition (2 studies). Positive or neutral effects include: similar growth rates (3 studies from Norway, Canada, Scotland), similar final body weights (2 studies from Norway), similar feeding efficiency (2 studies from Canada, Scotland), similar digestibility levels (2 studies), unaffected survival rates and appetite (2 studies), and increased condition in one study. Two replicated studies in Norway found similar final weights in salmon fed diets containing low, medium or high levels of fish meal.
summary_statements: Replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets has shown mixed effects.
Negative effects of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets include decreased growth rates.
Negative effects of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets include reduced final body weights.
Negative effects of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets include lowered feeding efficiency.
Negative effects of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets include reduced digestibility of feed components.
Negative effects of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets include altered intestinal morphology.
Negative effects of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets include a reduced condition.
Replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets can result in similar growth rates.
Replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets can result in similar final body weights.
Replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets can result in similar feeding efficiency.
Replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets can result in similar digestibility levels.
Replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets can leave survival rates and appetite unaffected.
Replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets can result in increased condition.
Salmon fed diets containing low, medium or high levels of fish meal were found to have similar final weights.

question_details.query: What does the evidence say about using probiotics, immunostimulants, or specific training to improve salmon survival against diseases?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence shows that probiotics and immunostimulants can improve salmon survival against diseases. A replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28-day period compared with controls (Action 732). The same research found that adding beta-glucans to salmon diet decreased lice infection levels by 28% compared with controls, and mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing soybean-induced enteritis (Action 732). Regarding training methods, a randomized, replicated, controlled study in Norway found higher survival rates in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis if they had undergone aerobic training, with interval training being more effective than continuous training (Action 740). Vaccinations were also shown to be effective, with multiple controlled studies demonstrating higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated controls when exposed to various bacterial diseases (Action 733).
summary_statements: The evidence shows that probiotics and immunostimulants can improve salmon survival against diseases.
A replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28-day period compared with controls.
Research found that adding beta-glucans to salmon diet decreased lice infection levels by 28% compared with controls.
Research found that mannan oligosaccharides improved salmon gut function by preventing soybean-induced enteritis.
A randomized, replicated, controlled study in Norway found higher survival rates in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis if the salmon had undergone aerobic training.
The study in Norway found interval training was more effective than continuous training for improving salmon survival.
Vaccinations were shown to be effective for improving salmon survival.
Multiple controlled studies demonstrated higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated controls when exposed to various bacterial diseases.

question_details.query: Based on studies in Australia, which husbandry practices have shown mixed or limited success in managing diseases and environmental impacts from salmon farming?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on studies in Australia, several salmon farming disease management practices have shown mixed or limited success. Studies on freshwater bathing to reduce amoebic gill disease found mixed results - while one study reported a reduction in gill amoebae persisting up to 10 days after bathing, controlled studies found similar levels of amoebae in treated and untreated salmon (Action ID: 739). Fallowing practices also showed mixed results, with one study finding no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages using fallowing systems, though fallowing did improve sediment community conditions (Action ID: 1026, 1027). Vaccination studies showed positive results internationally, but the evidence base for Australia's salmon farming was not specifically detailed as showing different outcomes from other regions (Action ID: 733).
summary_statements: Based on studies in Australia, several salmon farming disease management practices have shown mixed or limited success.
Studies on freshwater bathing to reduce amoebic gill disease found mixed results.
One study reported a reduction in gill amoebae persisting up to 10 days after freshwater bathing.
Controlled studies found similar levels of amoebae in treated salmon and untreated salmon.
Fallowing practices also showed mixed results.
One study found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages using fallowing systems.
Fallowing did improve sediment community conditions.
Vaccination studies showed positive results internationally.
The evidence base for Australia's salmon farming was not specifically detailed as showing different outcomes from other regions.
